title: Distribution
historical_context: This article reflects the early days of online magazine distribution and the transition from BBS to web hosting.
target_audience: Hackers, virus developers, and those interested in underground publications.
short_summary: The article discusses the distribution of 29A Magazine, including changes in hosting and how contributors can get involved. It highlights the shift from BBS to web platforms for sharing content.
summary:
In this article, the 29A Magazine team provides an update on their distribution methods, noting the challenges they faced in maintaining a stable online presence. They mention their current homepage URLs and express gratitude to Source of Kaos for hosting. The team invites contributions for future issues, emphasizing their quality standards and the right to reject submissions that do not meet their expectations. They also encourage BBS operators to reach out if they wish to distribute the magazine, although they acknowledge the declining relevance of BBSs in favor of web-based platforms.

The article serves as a snapshot of the magazine's efforts to adapt to the changing landscape of digital communication in the late 1990s. It highlights the community aspect of hacker culture, where collaboration and sharing of knowledge are paramount. The mention of various team members' personal homepages underscores the decentralized nature of information dissemination among hackers and virus developers at the time.
